document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Neotropical genus Macreupelmus Ashmead (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eupelmidae)

erwini

. Holotype point-mounted by meso- and metacoxae; entire; uncontorted.

Etymology. Named in honor of Terry Erwin, Smithsonian Institution, Washington , DC, USA , who collected the holotype of this species as well as specimens of other species through his innovative collecting technique of insecticidal fogging, which has resulted in the collection of numerous eupelmids over the years.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 72–80 .
Macreupelmus erwini
n. sp. 72 & 73 (holotype): 72 , lateral habitus; 73 , face. 74–76 , 2016-12: 74 , antenna; 75 , fore wing; 76 , medial part of fore wing. 77–80 , holotype: 77 , dorsal habitus; 78 , frons; 79 , anterior part of body, uncontorted condition; 80 , dorsal mesosoma.

FIGURES 81–86 .
Macreupelmus erwini
n. sp. 81 , fore wing costal cell (holotype). 82–84 , 2016-11: 82 , metafemur; 83 , middle leg, posterior view; 84 , middle leg, tibial apex and base of tarsus. 85 & 86 , holotype: 85 , propodeal plical region; 86 , Gt6, posterolateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Although the propodeal plical region superficially appears long medially, the anterior margin is actually deeply incised with contiguous or only narrowly separated margins so as often to appear to have a median sulcus anterior to a posterior lunate region along the foramen ( Fig. 85 ). Except for the fore wing having a hyaline region with white setae extending from the submarginal vein at the boundary between the more hyaline basal cell and infuscate disc ( Figs 75, 76 ), females of
M. erwini
closely resemble those of
M. granulosus
because of a similar superficially long propodeal plical region ( cf. Figs 85 , 94 ), a granular Gt6 ( cf. Figs 86 , 95 ), quite an extensive reddish-violaceous to purple or blue region on the gena behind the outer orbit ( cf. Figs 79 , 88 ), and a more cylindrical scape so that the apex of the pedicel extends for a short, though quite obvious distance beyond the ventral margin of the scape when held at a right angle to the scape ( cf. Figs 74 , 88 ). This latter feature is also similar to that of
M. auranticrus
( Fig. 21 , insert).
